commentBody: Pretty cool puzzle!

A more appropriate theme could not have been imagined for where I am sitting right now, as my struggling CENTRAL AC is barely keeping up with the weather we've been having the past few days.

At least they say it peaked today, with tomorrow being a bit cooler, Thursday being normal (high of 77) and Friday downright chilly (never getting to 70).

Well. That was a cool breeze.

Not sure why ‚Äúblade‚Äù is in quotes in 44A. That‚Äôs literally what rowers call the oars. (More technically, ‚Äúblade‚Äù refers to just the end that goes in the water, rather than the whole thing including shaft and handle, but the terms are often used interchangeably)
Yes I suppose it‚Äôs not truly a blade in the sense of being sharp (though I don‚Äôt think Olympic epees are actually that sharp either, are they?), but it‚Äôs a technical term, not slang

I moved apartments recently to lower my rent. And lost Central AC in the process. However, shady trees help. Relatively easy Wednesday. I think maybe that's why I keep spelling it SAO PAOLO (I get the Portuguese and Italian versions of Paulo/Paolo mixed up). Well that's my excuse. Hopefully from now on I'll remember!

When a neighbor, and later we, had some trees taken down, the tree companies came back with a stump grinder, which made short work of both large and small tree stumps, taking them down to slightly below ground level. So, UPROOTER was a term that was unfamiliar.

Shortly before our house in Wisconsin sold, our AC unit had stopped cooling, apparently due to a slow refrigerant leak. The unit itself was over 30 years old at the time, and we'd been warned it was on it's last legs for the last five years, but once the tech charged it back up, it was cooling the house again.

I feel a little sympathy for the folks experiencing the heat, but we haven't really seen anything out of the ordinary here in central Florida. Highs in the low 90s to high 80s, with almost daily thunderstorms, and CENTRAL AC is always a necessity.

Nice puzzle, Ben and Zach, and thanks!

Well done NYC! Brave choice and I salud you. 

Just in Brooklyn yesterday visiting my son. Soon as I got out of the car, heat hit me with a THUMP -- so it's very apt to do an A/C grid on the hottest day of the year. We sallied forth to Greenpoint to lunch at one of those hallowed old Polish restaurants: cool cucumber salad, carrot & horseradish salad, beet salad, cold bright pink borscht, bottle after bottle of Lech... Andrzej, you were in my thoughts...and still it wasn't enough to keep us from wilting in the 100 degree blast. My son's friend said the weatherman has been saying it's a "heat bubble." 

Opi! It's your year; xwordinfo says you've been used six times so far and we're not even in July, maybe it'll be a ninefold Opi year. I like their clever names. And there are some good possibilities here in this grid. If I were a "brand ambassador" for Opi, these are some of the shades I'd be promoting (based on this puzzle): 

Egg Salud 
U-Boat Oar 
Sober Toad

Plasma Clinic USA 
Ban Avian Liu

So happy to be out of the heat. Stay icee...
Solid Wursday puzzle.

I abandoned the solve when it turned out (by my revealing two entries) one of the rebuses was at the cross of an American brand and the informal name of a singer from the 60s. How on Earth could I know any of those entries, and well enough to be confident about the rebus square? I know it's what I get for solving an American puzzle as a Polish guy, and one born in 1980 rather than 1950, but I don't have to like it.

For me the puzzle was saturated with arcana, and even though I got the trick (or at least I realized I had to put AC into four squares, of which I got two myself before I gave up solving), the grid was largely empty well into my attempt. I did not know so many of the answers I decided to reveal them rather than look them up, and that cross of two trivia entries spoiled the whole thing for me.

This was one of the least personally enjoyable puzzles I have ever attempted to solve in the NYT.

On another topic--another game: There WERE 4 words that could have had BERRY after them and yet that collection was considered wrong in Connections.

I really dislike this game because it's really all about what's in the constructor's mind--not what is correct. It's so frustrating and it's been awful lately.

I remember first reading The Rime of the Ancient Mariner in high school and cheering the spirits tormenting him for killing the albatross, not to mention applauding the crew for hanging the dead bird around his neck. After all, think about it‚Äîdo you know of any ballads written about sailors with punitive tofurkey collars? 

Then there‚Äôs L‚ÄôAlbatross by Baudelaire, where the allegory is meant to make you feel for the poet‚Äôs alienation. Teen angst notwithstanding, I thought Baudelaire was a whiner and I felt for the actual bird instead. (Maybe those PETA and ASPCA memberships were preordained?)

After that I didn‚Äôt think about albatrosses for 20 years until my husband got me to watch a documentary on them. Enormous, majestic birds who cover millions of miles in their lifetime, mate for life, and lay just one egg a year. I watched an albatross chick being fed. The mother had brought what was meant to be krill and jellyfish. Instead she poured clear plastic into her offspring‚Äôs throat. The birds mistake discarded plastic bags floating in the water for jellyfish, then inadvertently feed it to their young. 

I‚Äôve been bringing my own paper bags to the produce section ever since. Recycling plastic bags in Europe is easier, but back home we‚Äôd fill a big box of them in the garage and cart it off twice a year to one of only 2 recycling facilities in Seattle metro that accepts this stuff. They make park benches out of it. Which is much better than feeding it to baby albatrosses.

Such a simple, elegant and perfect-for-crosswords theme.  Props to the constructors for plucking it out of the ether and so ably executing it.

The grid design allows for thirteen longs, and twelve of those were appealing, IMO, giving the box plenty of pop. Twelve of thirteen!  Bolstered by beauty in short answers (THUMP, BEADY, PALETTE).  

I also liked the unintended mini-theme of A TRAIN, with eight answer that have that letter as the caboose.  

But what I loved most were the answers that warmed my HEART, reminders of two so dear to me.  PET CAT and RESCUE brought my Wiley to mind ‚Äì he is both ‚Äì who I tremendously love despite being the hairball king of the world.  And SOBER immediately had me thinking about one of my children who has been that for many years, who is courageous beyond measure, and who I am so proud of.

A puzzle that delighted my mind and melted my heart.  That‚Äôs a wow.  Thank you so much for this, Ben and Zach!

The Lawsuit and Settlement:
Following the accident, Abbott sued the homeowner whose tree fell on him, as well as the tree care company that had inspected it.
His legal team was able to prove that the homeowner knew the tree had root rot and that the tree-trimming company had worsened its condition through chemical treatment.

(cont'd)
Abbott won a multimillion-dollar settlement which included payments for current and future medical bills, mental anguish, and some lost income.
The settlement was structured as an annuity, providing tax-free payments, including monthly income and periodic lump sums.
By 2013, Abbott had received $5.8 million, and continued to receive monthly payments for life and lump sums every three years until 2022.

The Aftermath and Political Life:
Abbott has used his story of triumph over adversity as a motivational tool during his campaigns, emphasizing his perseverance.
He has also become a vocal advocate for tort reform, which some critics point out seems contradictory given his own successful personal injury lawsuit. These critics argue that current tort reform laws in Texas make it significantly harder for individuals to obtain large settlements similar to his.
Abbott's lawyer at the time of the accident, Don Riddle, agrees that tort reform has made obtaining large settlements "next to impossible" in Texas today.

All this tree talk reminds me that people should respect trees.
Don't take shelter under trees during thunderstorms.
Don't jog on tree-lined streets when its stormy & windy
like the young Gregg Abbott did. Now, TX Gov. Gregg Abbott.

The compelling story of Greg Abbott and the tree begins in July 1984, when a 75-foot oak tree fell on him while he was jogging. Abbott, then a 26-year-old law school graduate, suffered severe injuries including a crushed spine, broken ribs, and damage to vital organs. The incident left him paralyzed from the waist down and reliant on a wheelchair.

The Accident and Recovery:
While jogging through the River Oaks neighborhood in Houston, a large oak tree snapped at its base and fell directly on Abbott's back.
He was rushed to the hospital where doctors worked to repair his damaged spine, inserting two steel rods near it.
Despite the severe injuries, Abbott has cited his faith and the concept of perseverance as crucial to his recovery. He has stated that the "accident broke my back, but not my spirit".
(cont'd)

@Jane Wheelaghan

The meaning of "punt" in this sense probably comes from American football, where the punt is one of two main kinds of kick.To see why, you need a little context.

The team in possession of the ball has four plays, called downs, to move the ball ten yards. Once they accomplish that, the process repeats until the team scores or is unsuccessful.

If a team runs a regular play on fourth down, which is to say they run or pass the ball forward, and is unsuccessful, the opponents take over at that point on the field.

If they are close enough to their opponent's goalposts, a team can attempt to kick the ball, held by a teammate the tall way on the ground, through them for a field goal (3 points). If it's too far away to attempt a field goal, the team has one more option: to PUNT. 

PUNTing is when the team on offense kicks the ball, dropped from the punter's hands and kicked before it hits the ground, as far away as possible within the field of play.  The purpose of this is to relinquish the ball to the other team, but to pin them back deep in the other end of the field, so that as they come on offense, they're practically the whole length of the field away from the opposing goal line.  Good punters can kick the ball a good 50-60 yards,

Figuratively, one PUNTs a decision down the road or until later for similar reasons: to create distance, because they don't want to handle it, etc.
